“We can help our veterans,” he said. “We can help those by giving them the ability to have something to get them through the times that whenever they close their eyes, the only things they see is the faces of the ones they served with that didn’t come home.” 
“It’s a gateway away from opioids," he added. "A gateway to a better life for somebody that may only have two months to live.” 
From here, the bill will now go through the State House of Representatives and, if it passes, to the governor's desk for approval. The state's governor, Jim Justice, has been an ardent supporter of medical marijuana. However, the House has been less enthusiastic about the possibility. Just two days ago, they failed to pass their own medical marijuana measure, which raises concerns about the likelihood of 368 passing. Perhaps if they read what experts have to say about the drug , they'll make the same decision that 28 other states have already made.
